clinical_study.brief_title: Finding Atrial Fibrillation in Stroke - Evaluation of Enhanced and Prolonged Holter Monitoring
clinical_study.official_title: A Prospective, Randomised, Controlled Study to Determine the Detection of Atrial Fibrillation by Prolonged and Enhanced Holter Monitoring as Compared to Usual Care in Stroke Patients

lead_sponsor.agency: Institut fuer anwendungsorientierte Forschung und klinische Studien GmbH

clinical_study.source: Institut fuer anwendungsorientierte Forschung und klinische Studien GmbH

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to assess whether repeated enhanced and prolonged ECG monitoring after ischemic stroke results in a higher detection of atrial fibrillation (/flutter) compared to usual care (at least 24 hour of cardiac monitoring).

primary_outcome.description: The primary endpoint is the detection of newly diagnosed atrial fibrillation/flutter within 6 months and before occurrence of recurrent stroke or systemic embolism in the treatment group compared to control group.

secondary_outcome.measure: number of atrial fibrillation (/flutter) within 12 months after patient's inclusion
secondary_outcome.description: Detection of newly diagnosed atrial fibrillation (/flutter) as defined for the primary endpoint but within 12 months after patient's inclusion. As patients are recruited for 12 months, this outcome measure is determined 24 months after study start.

secondary_outcome.measure: number of atrial fibrillation (/flutter) without hospitalisation
secondary_outcome.description: Detection of newly diagnosed atrial fibrillation (/flutter) as defined for the primary endpoint with the exception that hospitalisation for atrial fibrillation (/flutter) will be considered as censoring.

secondary_outcome.measure: number of recurrent stroke or systemic embolism
secondary_outcome.description: Recurrent stroke or systemic embolism within 12 months after patient's inclusion. As patients are recruited for 12 months, this outcome measure is determined 24 months after study start.
Total death within 12 months after patient's inclusion. As patients are recruited for 12 months, this outcome measure is determined 24 months after study start.

secondary_outcome.measure: number of atrial fibrillation (/flutter) in extended monitoring period
secondary_outcome.description: Incremental detection of atrial fibrillation (/flutter) in the extended Holter monitoring periods after 3 and 6 months.
To assess the feasibility of monitoring procedures.

arm_group.description: Prolonged ECG monitoring: 10-day Holter ECG at months 0, 3 and 6
Usual care according to current guidelines (minimum of 24 hours of cardiac monitoring).

intervention.description: Usual care according to current guidelines (minimum of 24 hours of cardiac monitoring).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Recent cerebral ischemia defined as stroke (sudden focal neurologic deficit lasting > 24h consistent with the territory of a major cerebral artery and categorised as ischemic) and/or a corresponding lesion on brain imaging.
- Stroke symptoms started ≤ 7 days ago.
- Age ≥ 60 years.
- Modified Rankin scale ≤ 2 (prior to index event).
Exclusion Criteria:
- Known history of atrial fibrillation/flutter or atrial fibrillation/flutter on admission ECG.
- Indication for oral anticoagulation at randomisation.
- Absolute contra-indication against oral anticoagulation at randomisation.
- Intracerebral bleeding in medical history.
- Patient scheduled for Holter-ECG or cardiac Event-Recording monitoring ≥ 48 hours.
- Significant carotid artery or vertebral artery stenosis > 50% (NASCET classification), significant intracranial artery stenosis suspicious of atherosclerotic origin or acute arterial dissection explanatory of stroke symptoms.
- Implanted pacemaker device or cardioverter/defibrillator.
- Life expectancy < 1 year for reasons other than stroke (e.g. metastatic cancer).
- Concomitant participation in other controlled randomised trial.
